ygData.subject: Re: New Paper on the Problem with Objectives in Evolution

Subject: Re: New Paper on the Problem with Objectives in Evolution
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=wg3UdNuPnYz8meLoyAP5gUkNa69upWTOag5xOGiWK0RNbQBNz4pn

Daniel, I appreciate very much you sharing your thoughts.  We were hoping=
 to provoke just such discussion with this paper and your questions highlig=
ht important issues.  Let me try to respond below...

> -----Original Messa=
ge-----
> From: Kenneth Stanley [mailto:kstanley@...]
> Sent: Satu=
rday, April 02, 2011 2:57 AM
> To: 'Kenneth Stanley'
> Subject: todelete2
>=
 
> Ken,
> 
> First off, I'll say that what I take as the central point, th=
at EAs can
> miss
> critical intermediate  objectives because they are awkw=
ardly placed on the
> fitness landscape, is a good one.  However, I have so=
me concerns about the
> experimental design in this paper:
> 
> (1) You app=
ear to be manipulating two variables at once.  (a) whether the
> EA
> has a=
n objective and (b) whether there is a human in the loop.  Surely you
> hav=
e to pick only one at a time and control for everything else, right?
> 

It=
's only a problem if you believe that somehow a human would do better at ev=
olving to these objectives, which of course humans would not.  Good luck to=
 anyone who wants to re-evolve the skull from scratch again.  It will never=
 happen.  Nor will anyone evolve any reasonably complex *preconceived* pict=
ure from scratch no matter where it came from, whether once evolved in the =
past or not.

On the other hand if you want to see non-objective search wit=
hout a human in the loop, that's what we've been doing with novelty search,=
 so there is plenty of literature on that combination at this point.  You c=
an find a lot here:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/noveltysearch/userspage/

Let =
me suggest to you or anyone who remains a skeptic (which is perfectly reaso=
nable) to check out my talk on the topic (recorded in video), which lays ou=
t the ideas much more broadly.  It's only 70 minutes and I think you will f=
ind it worth the time to see how I try to defend this counter-intuitive pos=
ition, if nothing else to stimulate some thinking even if you still feel sk=
eptical:

http://www.infoq.com/presentations/Searching-Without-Objectives

=

> (2) Furthermore, if it's IGA v. GA and 'interestingness' is the evaluati=
on
> criteria, that ain't a fair fight.  Why should I believe there is more=
 to
> it
> than that?
> 

But interestingness wasn't the evaluation criteri=
a.  This paper played by the traditional ground rules to whose defense you =
are now jumping.  The objective was definitively the skull (or the butterfl=
y, or the eye..), not "interestingness."  The fact that the results come ou=
t so abysmally and leave you wanting to argue about interestingness just sh=
ows how unreasonable peddling these objectives as meaningful benchmarks can=
 be.  That's the whole point - the paper is a play on the traditional algor=
ithmic evaluation scheme that leaves the reader squirming, as it should.  
=

In fact, if you really think that IGA vs. GA isn't a "fair fight" when we =
are aiming for interestingness, then you are in part in agreement (though i=
nadvertently) with the spirit of our message.  That is, if you are really c=
onvinced that IGA is so far superior to GAs at doing something interesting =
that it isn't even fair to contrast them, then unless we are somehow intent=
ionally trying to avoid evolving anything interesting, what are we doing wa=
sting our time with objective GAs?  Does it not highlight a central paradox=
 in our position that we might actually care more about being "fair" than b=
eing "interesting?"  Why are we even running these algorithms?

> (3) How d=
o we know that intermediate objectives are in any way significant
> to disc=
overing interesting pictures in Picbreeder?  I have a sneaking
> suspicion =
that totally random search, followed by focused objective based
> search wh=
en something 'pops' might be just as effective, and that the
> 'intermediat=
e objectives', while certainly necessary to find a particular
> image, are =
not very helpful in general to finding interesting images.  If
> so, this i=
s no chink in the armor of objective based search.  I suppose
> without int=
ermediate objectives there can be no exaptation, but does that
> matter?  W=
hat percentage of evolved features in biological organisms have
> any exapt=
ation at all in their history?
> 

When you say the random search followed =
by objective-based search would be "just as effective," I don't really unde=
rstand: just as effective at what?  At doing something "interesting?"  At a=
chieving a specific objective?  Surely you don't believe that random search=
 will produce images as interesting as Picbreeder?  The stepping stones (i.=
e. intermediate objectives) in Picbreeder are in effect fundamental discove=
ries of important regularities that are later elaborated.  For example, thi=
s simple face-like stepping stone leads to a whole family of subsequent fac=
es:

http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D542

Here you can ge=
t a family-tree expansion from that individual: 
http://picbreeder.org/sear=
ch/familytree.php?sid=3D542

If you are willing to skip bridges like that b=
ecause they are intermediate, you would never find any of the treasures on =
the other side of the bridge.  If you look back in the lineages of almost a=
ny interesting image on the site you will find a similar story wherein fund=
amental regularities that were later exploited were first discovered in a d=
ifferent context.  

Just compare figure 6 and figure 7 in the paper to see=
 how horrible it is to start from a random place and then lock in on an obj=
ective (figure 7).  It takes 29,000 generations to do the same thing it too=
k 12 to do better.


> (4) Finally - and this is the big one - one of the d=
eadly sins of Science
> is
> claiming a result as the objective a posterior=
i, a point which eludes even
> some very famous scientists.  It's what allo=
ws publications like this,
> which
> 'prove' psychic phenomena by mining da=
ta for 'statistically significant'
> results.  The problem is, a result isn=
't significant unless you were
> specifically attempting to confirm it when=
 the experiment was designed
> (i.e.
> always follow up exploratory experim=
ent with a confirmatory experiment!).
> I
> heartily endorse exploring for/=
marvelling at results you weren't initially
> looking for, but one should n=
ever use such results as the basis for any
> sort	
> of comparison.  In the=
 case of the eye experiment, who cares if the GA
> couldn't evolve the eye?=
  The IGA can't either, and the fact that it
> already
> did is immaterial!=
  I could be persuaded that the IGA is better at evolving
> interesting ima=
ges, but I do not believe it's any better at evolving the
> 'eye' (or 'dolp=
hin', or 'apple').  In fact, I would bet that's it's worse
> at
> evolving =
those specific images, intermediate objectives notwithstanding.
> 

Should =
we really believe your statement? : "I heartily endorse exploring for/marve=
lling at results you weren't initially looking for, but one should never us=
e such results as the basis for any sort of comparison."

Is not our entire=
 infatuation with evolution, the very reason we choose to explore it as an =
algorithm, for the very reason that you say we should never use such compar=
isons?  After all, natural evolution is just such a gallery of "results you=
 weren't initially looking for" yet it is the core inspiration for all our =
hopes and dreams for the field and the example against which many of us com=
pare our algorithms.  Thus I strongly disagree with the principle you want =
to impose that marvels attained without explicit a priori intent are outsid=
e of the realm of scientific interest.  On the contrary, in fact the point =
of the paper is that our mistake is precisely that we have been misled by s=
uch a restrictive and dogmatic doctrine.  It is time that we did begin to c=
ontemplate the marvel of what is discovered a posteriori.  Asking why such =
amazing discoveries as human beings happens in nature is nothing like enter=
taining psychic phenomena.

Imagine if we had left out the part about Picbr=
eeder and simply run some experiments to see if NEAT can evolve a set of pi=
ctures.  After it failed miserably every time, following the traditional in=
terpretation, we would conclude that NEAT cannot evolve such pictures, or e=
ven pictures *like* them.  The fact that Picbreeder did evolve many such pi=
ctures is thus relevant and scientifically interesting; it shows why the tr=
aditional implications we draw from such "failures" are far too expansive.
=

You say that you could be persuaded that the IGA is better at evolving int=
eresting images yet then you say that you don't think it is better at evolv=
ing the eye.  Yet the whole point is that it is better at evolving interest=
ing images.  Beware of missing the forest for the trees:  It is not importa=
nt whether the IGA is good at evolving the eye (or dolphin, or apple); it i=
s important that it is good at evolving images *like* those.  There is no o=
ther algorithm on Earth that can do that.  That is, there is no other appro=
ach that we know of that could get NEAT to actually encode images *like* ca=
rs and butterflies in a CPPN.  That fact should be startling to us, not dis=
missed as a mere curiosity.  


> Anyway, though I have a lot of doubts abo=
ut this particular paper, I really
> appreciate these sorts of research dir=
ections.  Keep up the good work!
> 

Sure, I understand.  A good hard defen=
se of the status quo is healthy to ensure that no one gets away with taking=
 unjustifiable potshots :)  Yet at the same time, questioning the status qu=
o is sometimes important if progress is to be made.  

Regards,

ken
